title: Question 138

children: A 51-year-old man is evaluated for persistent fever, cough, and worsening dyspnea after completing appropriate antibiotic therapy for community-acquired pneumonia.

Temperature is 38.1 °C (100.7 °F), pulse rate is 90/min, and respiration rate is 25/min. Breath sounds are decreased over the lower left hemithorax. A lateral decubitus radiograph shows a left-sided, 1.5-cm pleural effusion. Ultrasound shows a pleural effusion with loculations.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Complicated parapneumonic effusion and empyema should be suspected in all patients who do not respond to appropriate antibiotic therapy for pneumonia.
Any pleural effusion greater than 1 cm in depth on a lateral decubitus radiograph that is associated with pneumonia should be investigated with diagnostic thoracentesis.
The most appropriate management is to perform diagnostic thoracentesis (

). Complicated parapneumonic effusion and empyema should be suspected in all patients who do not respond to appropriate antibiotic therapy for pneumonia. This patient has fever and worsening dyspnea after completing antibiotic therapy for pneumonia, as well as a pleural effusion associated with recent bacterial pneumonia that is consistent with parapneumonic effusion. Any pleural effusion greater than 1 cm in depth on a lateral decubitus radiograph that is associated with pneumonia should be investigated with diagnostic thoracentesis. The radiograph suggests an uncomplicated, free-flowing effusion, but the ultrasound reveals details (including loculations) that indicate a complicated effusion. Diagnostic thoracentesis should be performed, with the resulting fluid examined for pH, cell count with differential, Gram stain, glucose, and culture; culture bottles should be directly inoculated at the bedside to increase yield. Parapneumonic effusions can be uncomplicated (sterile and free flowing) or complicated (infected and typically loculated). Empyema refers to collection of purulent fluid in the pleural space.

Pleural drainage is indicated if the pleural fluid analysis shows a positive Gram stain (or culture), pus, glucose level less than 40 to 60 mg/dL (2.2-3.3 mmol/L), or pH less than 7.2. Options for drainage include thoracostomy tube (

) with or without the combined use of intrapleural fibrinolytics (streptokinase, urokinase, tissue plasminogen activator) and a mucolytic agent (deoxyribonuclease, or DNase) or surgical intervention via video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (
). There is controversy regarding which approach is best. Diagnostic thoracentesis should be performed in this patient before consideration of a drainage strategy.
